VOL. XV, NO. 8.

HOPKINS FIGHTS GAMELY
Black and Blue Plays Beautiful Game
Against Carlisle—Dodson, Musser
and Riley are Stars.

Before a crowd of four thousand
people, Hopkins played its first
game with a college of national
football reputation, and "made
good." The score, although 12 to
0, does not indicate the closeness
of the game, for to make the twelve
Points the Indians not only had to
fight for all that was in them, but
they had to spring almost their
entire list of trick plays, for which
they have been famous this year.
The team that held Princeton 6 to
o had its hands full with Hopkins,
and it was by merest chance that
Hopkins did not score nine points
three by Stonie's beautiful dropkick, and six by Dodson's wonderful run.
Dodson and Musser at the ends
were invincible. Despite the fact
that the Indians had a great reputation for making .end runs with
their fast back-field, when they
tried them on Hopkins they were
miserable failures, and in most
cases the runner was thrown for
a loss. And on the punts either
Dodson or Musser would drop the
Indian in his tracks the instant he
had caught the ball.
In the back-field, Riley and Stollenwerck were the stars. Riley
tore great holes in the Indians' line,
going through, once for a run of
forty yards. Stollenwerck made
the prettiest drop-kick that Homewood has ever witnessed from the
Indians' 45-yard line. Dame Fortune willed, however, that Hopkins
should not score, for the ball, instead of going over, hit an upright
of the goal-posts and bounced back.
Pieper and Gillet were also good,
and Schaefer, Penniman, and
liehael on the line played a strong
game.
All through the game luck was
With the Indians. That Stonie's
kick didn't go over was luck; and
that KennerlY, the Indians' fast
right end, should be more fleet of
foot than Dodson was pure luck.
Referee Greshham Poe blew his
Whistle at 2.30 on the dot, and with
the sound still in the air Powell,
of the Indians, kicked to Hopkins
5-yard line. Riley ran the ball
back five yards.
Pieper tore
through the Indians for five yards
more. Then they braced and held
nopkins for two downs.
Gillet kicked and Musser downed
the Indian as he caught the ball.
Carlisle fumbled and Pieper recovered it, on Hopkins 35-yard line.
Gillet was given the leather, and he

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 21, 1910.
got away with thirty yards before
the Redskins downed him.
Hopkins was held for two
downs and Stonie made a try at
goal from Carlisle's 45-yard line.
The ball hit against a goal post,
and, not as in the St. Johns game,
Carlisle rerebounded inside.
covered the ball, but was held for
down's and kicked. Stonie caught
it, but was thrown before he could
get started.
Riley made a sensational run
through the Indians for forty yards,
but unfortunately fumbled the ball
when he was tackled. Carlisle
recovered it, and went down the
field by line 'plunging. The first
quarter ended with the ball in
Carlisle's possession.
In the first two minutes of the
second quarter, Dupuis, by a trick
play, went through the Hopkins
line, and, before he could be stopped, made a touchdown. Powell
kicked goal.
The Indians kicked to Hopkins,
but the ball fell behind the. goal
posts. It was brought out and put
in scrimmage, on Hopkins' 25-yard
line. Belt went in at center, as
McCabe had received a knock on
his lame ankle. Dodson on the
next play made thirty-five yards on
a forward pass. Hopkins tried
another forward pass, but it failed,
and . the Indians got -the ball.
Carisle kicked and Stonie ran the
ball back ten yards. The first half
ended with the ball in Hopkins'
possession on its 40-yard line.
The beginning of the second half
saw Dick McCabe back at center.
Carlisle kicked to Hopkins' io-yard
line. Gillet ran the ball back fwentyfive yards. The ball was fumble-d,
and lucky Carlisle recovered it.
On the next play the Indians
tried a double pass, but Dodson,
breaking through the line, caught
the ball when the Redskin passed
it, and with a clear field ahead of
him started for Carlisle's goal.
Had Dodson been a little faster a
touchdown would have been ineyitable, but Kennerly, the Indian's
speedy right end, caught him on
Carlisle's 20-yard line. As it was,
he made eighty yards.

PROF. OBERHUMMER LECTURES

Hopkins and Washington College Will
Clash at Homewood in Final
Game of the Year.

Noted Austrian Geographer Here and
Talks of Human Geography
in Many Phases.

A series of three lectures was
delivered in McCoy Hall, Monday,
Tuesday and Wednesday last by
Dr. Eugen Oberhummer, professor
of historical and political geography
in the University of Vienna.
1. The first lecture was devoted to the history of ;:he development of human geography as a
science distinct from physiography.
In very early antiquity, Dr. Oberhummer steted, in the times of
Pythagoras and Herodotus, two
kinds of geography were recognized — scientific and historical.
During the ignorance of the Middle
Ages and the scientific fervor of
the Rennaissance, this distinction
was to a great extent lost sight of;
and it was not propounded again
until 1650, when Varenius divided
geography into two classes—mathematical and histcrical. The study
of historical geography increased
throughout the seventecnth and
eighteenth centuries; but it degenerated on the one hand into a mere
study of artificial political boundaries, and on the other of vast
masses of curious or statistical information. It is not here that we
must look for the beginnings of
human geography, which is the
study of the relations of man to
geographical surroundings. Those
beginnings are to be sought rather
in authors who had little idea of
writing geography—in Hippocrates
the physician among the ancients,
and in Montesquieu among the
moderns. The real establishment of
human geography as a science,
however, was the achievement of
Karl Rittet, a professor at the University of Berlin, whose stupendous
work on "Geography and Its Connections With the Nature and History of Man" was left unfinished
at his death in 1859. The progress
of the new science was considerably
furthered by the great Count Humboldt, notably in his "Political Essay
upon the State of New Spain."
After the influence of these illustrious pioneers had subsided, a reaction followed during which the
attention of nearly all geographers
was directed entirely upon the
scientific aspect of their subject. In
more recent years, however, the
study of human geography was
revived in a startling series of books

Hopkins will play the Washington College eleven of Chestertown,
on Thanksgiving Day, at Homewood. This game was definitely
scheduled by Manager Haynes last
week. Washington College has
been clamoring for a game for a
number of years, but until recently
it has not been considered worthy
of a place on the Hopkins schedule.
The situation was changed when
the Eastern Shore lads downed the
strong team of Rutgers College a
week ago. This victory was quite
a feather in the caps of Mike
Thompson's squad, as Rutgers had
played Navy a scoreless tie earlier
this season.
Now that Hopkins is going to
play the Chestertown aggregation,
it is expected that the Black and
Blue will win a decisive victory
and silence, once and forever, the
talk of the Washington College
players that Hopkins cannot claim
the state championship without
defeating them. If the Eastern
Shore team gives Hopkins a hard
fight, it will be justified in demanding to be taken into account in the
race for the state championship,
and in asking for a yearly game
with ,Hopkins; but if it is badly
defeated, it cannot object to being
omitted from the Hopkins schedules
in the future.
Hopkins probably will not be
represented by its full strength
Thursday, as Coach Lynn wants
to give the substitutes a chance.
Unless they are urgentl- needed,
several of the regular Hopkins
stars will probably warm the players' bench. Hopkins and Washington College are the only local
teams of any importance that will
play on Thanksgiving day. The
attendance, therefore, ought to be
large, as many people make it a
point not to let a Thanksgiving
day go by without seeing a football team. There are many Washington College alumni and sympathizers living in Baltimore, and
they" will be out in, full force to
cheer their favorites.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 21,

1910.

On account of the Thanksgiving
recess during the latter part of this
week, there will be no issue of
THE NEWS-LETTER on next Monday, November 28.
Our esteemed, if somewhat bluestockinged, contemporary, the New
Yory Evening Post, published a few
days ago a little article which had
the interesting title"Socialism on the
Campus." Quoting from a report
which had just been made public
by the Intercollegiate Socialist
Society, the Post, after enumerating
the colleges where there were
societies devoted to furthering the
the interests of this economic creed,
said that "promises of .additional
chapters have been made, according
to the report by the undergraduates
of Dartmouth, Johns Hopkins and
others."
This certainly is news to us. We
are not aware in the first place of
the existence of any socialistically
inclined students here at Hopkins,
and in the second place we do not
think that if there are any here,
they intend to form such a society
as the one described. If any such
plan is being considered, we wish
that it may be communicated to
THE NEWS-LETTER, so that we can
make an exclusive announcement
and can score a beat on our New
York contemporary.
With the organization this year
of the arbitration society we thought
that there were here at this Uniersity enough interests outside the
class-room, and when the musical
clubs were rejuvenated, this belief
was strenghtened. Apparently, if
the report of the Intercollegiate
Society is correct, we haven't
reached the end yet; and soon we
may have a Republican Club, a
Democratic Union, and a ProhibiStave off the
tion Sorority.
Socialistic society, please, as it
might serve as the forerunner for

criticism of a course that is required
of all undergraduates, we wish to
remind our readers that THE NEWSLETTER takes no responsibility for
views that are thus made public
further than to make sure that they
are bona fide utterances of readers
of the paper.
In the present case we agree with
the general idea of less lecture and
more recitation in undergraduate
courses,though we are not at all sure
that all that is said of the particular
course mentioned is justified. The
gi ound covered by the minor physics
course is extensive and only a
superficial knowledge of the subject
as a whole can be expected. If
the grades in the course average as
high as those in other compulsory
courses—and we believe they do—
it is evident that a satisfactory mastery of the work is obtained by most
of the students. To increase the
number of hours per week would
permit of more intensive study of
the science; but this, we believe,
is not the purpose of the course,
nor should it be so long as every
undergraduate is required to pursue
it. A general acquaintance with
the elements of physics the University holds to be necessary for a
liberal education; thorough mastery
of the science is only to be obtained
by those who devote their best efforts to it for a long period.

THE NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 21, 1910

TELESCOPES AND CRABS
Astronomy and Biology Divide Time of
Scientific Association—Ames and
Andrews Report Summer Trips.

• The first of the monthly meetings of the Scientific Association
was held last Wednesday at four
o'clock, in Hopkins Hall. Two
very interesting papers were given:
one by Professor Ames on the
meeting of the International Society for Solar Research, at Mt.
'Wilson, and the other by Professor
n:Irews on the expedition sent by
the University to Jamaica last summer.
The International Society for
Solar Research was formed in St.
Louis nine years ago when a num'ber of famous scientists happened
to he present in that city. Six
Years ago a meeting was held at
Oxford, England; three years later
one was held in Paris ; and in 1913
the Society will meet in Bonn, Germany. The meeting was held at
Mt. Wilson this summer, lai-gely
as a compliment to Professor Hale,
who is today unsurpassed in astronomical research. Scientists from
all over the world were present,
about forty from Europe, and forty
from America. The work of the
Society is divided 'among a number of permanent commttees which
make reports at the tri-yearly meetings.- These committees are:
The Committee on Standard
Wave Lengths, of which Professor
Ames is a member.
The Committee on Solar Eclipses.
It is evident that in order that
there may be successful observations, there should be some agreenient between the observatories as
to what they are to look for during the eclipses. That is one of
the functions of this committee.
Its other duties are to propose
Problems for investigation and to
devise instruments for the observation of eclipses of the sun. One
important question now being investigated is that of the constancy
of solar radiation. It was first
Observed by Professor. Langley
that for about six weeks there was
a diminution in the solar radiation, after which period it returned
to the normal amount. It is expected that when we learn more•
about solar radiation, we shall be
able to predict changes in the
Weather more certainly.
The Committee on Sun Spots.
Sun spots have been under 'observation from the time of Galileo.

Some years ago Professor Hale,
the director of the Mt. Wilson
observatory, discovered evidences
of a magnetic field around the sun
spots. He noticed also that the
spectrum of light issuing from or
near the sun spots was very different from the spectrum of ordinary sunlight. These discoveries
suggested many heretofore unsuspected phenomena.
The Committee on the Spectroheliograph. The Spectroheliograph
is an instrument by means of which
it is possible to observe the sun
by colored light. The surface of
the sun presents very different appearances when seen through glass
plates of different colors. In this
way we can learn a great deal
about the atmospheric conditions
on the sun. The principal work.
of this committee is to see that
spectroheliographs are constructed
and installed in all the observatories of the world, so that a continual watch can be kept on the
surface of the sun.
The second paper of the meeting was read by Professor Andrews. Professor Andrews gave a
short account of the previous relations of Johns Hopkins with the
island of Jamaica, from the time
when Professor Brooks established
the first laboratory at Kingston in
1891, to the fateful expedition to
Port Antonio, on which Professor
Humphreys and Dr. Conant lost
their lives. Then Professor Andrews described the surroundings
of the laboratory, the river, the islands with their mangrove swamps,
the coral reefs, all of which furnished abundant material for study.
The meeting was livened up a
bit by the live cabs which Dr.
Andrews brought in, two hermit
crabs, a white crab, and a black
crab. The latter animal is much
esteemed by the Jamaicans for
food, and bears a reputation comparable to that of our soft crabs.
The hermit crabs live on the land;
but once a year they go down to
the sea, traveling in an absolutely
straight line, crawling over all obstacles instead of going around
them, in order to deposit in the
water the young ones -which they
carry with them. The young stay
in the water for some time. Then
they crawl out and pick up a snailshell in which to live, and travel
up to the mountains, where they
are usually found.
Professor Andrews showed a
myriad of shells which .were collected in ponds. They were of

two kinds, the one small and
light-colored, the other large and
dark-colored. The small ones and
large ones were found in the same
pond within a short distance of
one another, and apparently under
the same conditions. But it was
found that the water in which the
dark-colored ones grew was slightly more saline, which apparently
influenced the size and color of
the shells.
Dr. Andrews was forced to cut
his talk somewhat short, because
of the lecture in McCoy Hall. But
he said sufficient to show the great
value of these expeditions to the
tropics.
Medical Society Hears Papers.

The Johns Hopkins Hospital
Medical Society met on Monday
evening, November 14, in the Medical Ampitheatre. There was an
attendance of about one hundred
and fifty. The first paper was by
Drs. Wm. S. Thayer and Roger S.
Morris (read by the former) on
"Two Cases of Congenital Hemolytic Jaundice." The paper was illustrated by microscopic preparations. After its conclusion the subject was further discussed by Dr.
W. L. Moss.
, Dr. J. Staige Davis read a most
interesting article upon "Wounds
of the Scalp and Their Treatment
by Skin-Grafting." After reviewing the history of this subject he
reported cases which came under
his own direct observation, and
concluded with a series of lantern
slides illustrating the operations
discussed.
Lectures on History of Religions.

Professor J. J. M. de Groot, of
the University of Leyden, will give
six lectures in McCoy Hall at 5
p. in. His subject will be "The
Development of Religious Ideas
in China." .The topics and dates
are as follows:
November 23—The Tao or Order
of the Universe.
November 28—The Tao of Man.
November 30—Holiness.
December 2—Asceticism. The
Prolongation of Life.
December 5—Worship of the
Universe.
December 6—Social and Political Taoism.
Cards of admission will not be
requisite. The door will be closed
when the lecturer rises.

HARLEY TUTTLE CAVERLY, '13
Haney Tuttle Caverly,a student in
the second-year class of the Medical
School, died on Monday, Nov. 14,
in the Johns Hopkins Hospital. He
was attacked about two weeks before
with severe abdominal trouble, for
which two operations were performed in vain. Mr. Caverly was a
resident of Rutland, Vermont. He
was an A. B. of Dartmouth College
in the class of 1909.
At a meeting of his class on Wednesday, November 16, the following
resolutions were adopted:
"We, the members of the class of
1913 of Johns .Hopkins Medical
School, wish to express to the family of our esteemed and beloved
classmate, Harley Tuttle Caverly,
our deep appreciation of his life
among us, and to extend to them
our heartfelt sympathy in their
bereavement.
At a meeting of the class it was
decided that a copy of this expression of our affection and sympathy
be published in THE NEWS-LETTER."
The class also sent flowers to
the funeral, which will take place
in Rutland, Vt.
Lecture on French Comedy.

Professor Giroud, of Girard College, Philadelphia, delivered the
second ot his series of talks on
the French comedy of the Eighteenth Century, arranged by the Alliance Francaise, in McCoy Hall at
noon Saturday. The topic was
Lesage's —rurcaret." Professor
Giroud is well known in educational
circles and among the members of
the Baltimore group of the Alliance,
and his lectures are attracting considerable attention. There are nine
more in the course. Next Saturday M. Louis Delamarre, of the
City College of New York, will be
the lecturer, speaking on "French
Humorists."

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

Has it every occurred to any of
the innocent freshmen who are so
assiduously warned at the weekly
"Hygiene Lectures" to beware of
dirt, that the towels hanging in the
gymnasium are changed rather infrequently and may, therefore, be
the breeding place for the same
, germs for whose eradication the application of hygienic principles
labors? Does it not seem ironical
to the upper-classmen that the
building that contains exhibits of
advanced metods of pasteurization
and utensils for the thorough cleaning of drinking cups, should have
scattered through it cups used by
almost all members of the University, that are put in position once
and are replaced only when they
leak? Certainly an institution so
intimately connected as is ours with
the leading school of preventive
medicine in the country should be
more careful of its students.

as yet the boundaries are by no

2.
The second lecture was
occupied with a discussion of the
peoples of Europe, that meetingplace of races. Most of the races
belong, however, to the same great
type of humanity, the one which has
at various times been called the
white, the Mediterranean, and the
Caucasian to distinguish it from
the black, the red, the yellow, and
the brown types.
In Dr. Oberhummer's opinion,
the earliest appearance of man in
Europe was in the Paleolithic Age.
To be sure, various unfashioned instruments have been unearthed,
. which are by some supposed to
betray the existence of Neolithic
men; but the earliest human bones
discovered belong to the Paleolithic
Age. Several skulls dating from
this period have been found in Germany, and some complete skeletons
in France; but it is as yet uncertain
whether or not these are the relics
of the ancestors of man, or of some
collateral descendants of a common
ancestor.
There are traces,Dr.Oberhummer
said, that the whole west of Europe
was once inhabited by men of
negro type. The east was at the
same time occupied by a people
resembling the Mongols. The chief
distinguishing mark between these
two races is the shape of the skull,
which in the case of the former is
elongated, in that of the latter
broadened. At present there are
three .types of man in Europe: in
the north a type tall of stature,
long of skull, blond of complexion;
in the center a type stocky of stature,
long of skull, and dark of complexion (not Celtic but Siberian) ;
and in the Alps a peculiar type with
a small round skull and a middle
stature.
The blond type is peculiar to
Europe; and, furthermore, it was to
be found originally only in the
Scandinavian peninsula and on the
shores of the Baltic. A peculiar
fact is that at the time of the appearance of man in southern and
western Europe, all this territory
was covered with a great ice-sheet.
Evidently, the blond type is a composite of post-glacial origin.
Dr. Oberhummer warned his
audience not to place too much confidence in philology as an aid to
the study of ethnology. Language,
he said, was the product rather of
historical than ethnological events;
and cited the cases of the Roumanians and of the Basques to prove his
contention.

HOPKINS FIGHTS GAMELY
Black and Blue Plays Beautiful Game
Against Carlisle—Dodson, Musser
and Riley are Stars.

Before a crowd of four thousand
people, Hopkins played its first
game with a college of national
football reputation, and "made
good." The score, although 12 to
0, does not indicate the closeness
of the game, for to make the twelve
Points the Indians not only had to
fight for all that was in them, but
they had to spring almost their
entire list of trick plays, for which
they have been famous this year.
The team that held Princeton 6 to
o had its hands full with Hopkins,
and it was by merest chance that
Hopkins did not score nine points
three by Stonie's beautiful dropkick, and six by Dodson's wonderful run.
Dodson and Musser at the ends
were invincible. Despite the fact
that the Indians had a great reputation for making .end runs with
their fast back-field, when they
tried them on Hopkins they were
miserable failures, and in most
cases the runner was thrown for
a loss. And on the punts either
Dodson or Musser would drop the
Indian in his tracks the instant he
had caught the ball.
In the back-field, Riley and Stollenwerck were the stars. Riley
tore great holes in the Indians' line,
going through, once for a run of
forty yards. Stollenwerck made
the prettiest drop-kick that Homewood has ever witnessed from the
Indians' 45-yard line. Dame Fortune willed, however, that Hopkins
should not score, for the ball, instead of going over, hit an upright
of the goal-posts and bounced back.
Pieper and Gillet were also good,
and Schaefer, Penniman, and
liehael on the line played a strong
game.
All through the game luck was
With the Indians. That Stonie's
kick didn't go over was luck; and
that KennerlY, the Indians' fast
right end, should be more fleet of
foot than Dodson was pure luck.
Referee Greshham Poe blew his
Whistle at 2.30 on the dot, and with
the sound still in the air Powell,
of the Indians, kicked to Hopkins
5-yard line. Riley ran the ball
back five yards.
Pieper tore
through the Indians for five yards
more. Then they braced and held
nopkins for two downs.
Gillet kicked and Musser downed
the Indian as he caught the ball.
Carlisle fumbled and Pieper recovered it, on Hopkins 35-yard line.
Gillet was given the leather, and he

PROF. OBERHUMMER LECTURES

Hopkins and Washington College Will
Clash at Homewood in Final
Game of the Year.

Noted Austrian Geographer Here and
Talks of Human Geography
in Many Phases.

A series of three lectures was
delivered in McCoy Hall, Monday,
Tuesday and Wednesday last by
Dr. Eugen Oberhummer, professor
of historical and political geography
in the University of Vienna.
1. The first lecture was devoted to the history of ;:he development of human geography as a
science distinct from physiography.
In very early antiquity, Dr. Oberhummer steted, in the times of
Pythagoras and Herodotus, two
kinds of geography were recognized — scientific and historical.
During the ignorance of the Middle
Ages and the scientific fervor of
the Rennaissance, this distinction
was to a great extent lost sight of;
and it was not propounded again
until 1650, when Varenius divided
geography into two classes—mathematical and histcrical. The study
of historical geography increased
throughout the seventecnth and
eighteenth centuries; but it degenerated on the one hand into a mere
study of artificial political boundaries, and on the other of vast
masses of curious or statistical information. It is not here that we
must look for the beginnings of
human geography, which is the
study of the relations of man to
geographical surroundings. Those
beginnings are to be sought rather
in authors who had little idea of
writing geography—in Hippocrates
the physician among the ancients,
and in Montesquieu among the
moderns. The real establishment of
human geography as a science,
however, was the achievement of
Karl Rittet, a professor at the University of Berlin, whose stupendous
work on "Geography and Its Connections With the Nature and History of Man" was left unfinished
at his death in 1859. The progress
of the new science was considerably
furthered by the great Count Humboldt, notably in his "Political Essay
upon the State of New Spain."
After the influence of these illustrious pioneers had subsided, a reaction followed during which the
attention of nearly all geographers
was directed entirely upon the
scientific aspect of their subject. In
more recent years, however, the
study of human geography was
revived in a startling series of books

Hopkins will play the Washington College eleven of Chestertown,
on Thanksgiving Day, at Homewood. This game was definitely
scheduled by Manager Haynes last
week. Washington College has
been clamoring for a game for a
number of years, but until recently
it has not been considered worthy
of a place on the Hopkins schedule.
The situation was changed when
the Eastern Shore lads downed the
strong team of Rutgers College a
week ago. This victory was quite
a feather in the caps of Mike
Thompson's squad, as Rutgers had
played Navy a scoreless tie earlier
this season.
Now that Hopkins is going to
play the Chestertown aggregation,
it is expected that the Black and
Blue will win a decisive victory
and silence, once and forever, the
talk of the Washington College
players that Hopkins cannot claim
the state championship without
defeating them. If the Eastern
Shore team gives Hopkins a hard
fight, it will be justified in demanding to be taken into account in the
race for the state championship,
and in asking for a yearly game
with ,Hopkins; but if it is badly
defeated, it cannot object to being
omitted from the Hopkins schedules
in the future.
Hopkins probably will not be
represented by its full strength
Thursday, as Coach Lynn wants
to give the substitutes a chance.
Unless they are urgentl- needed,
several of the regular Hopkins
stars will probably warm the players' bench. Hopkins and Washington College are the only local
teams of any importance that will
play on Thanksgiving day. The
attendance, therefore, ought to be
large, as many people make it a
point not to let a Thanksgiving
day go by without seeing a football team. There are many Washington College alumni and sympathizers living in Baltimore, and
they" will be out in, full force to
cheer their favorites.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 21,

1910.

On account of the Thanksgiving
recess during the latter part of this
week, there will be no issue of
THE NEWS-LETTER on next Monday, November 28.
Our esteemed, if somewhat bluestockinged, contemporary, the New
Yory Evening Post, published a few
days ago a little article which had
the interesting title"Socialism on the
Campus." Quoting from a report
which had just been made public
by the Intercollegiate Socialist
Society, the Post, after enumerating
the colleges where there were
societies devoted to furthering the
the interests of this economic creed,
said that "promises of .additional
chapters have been made, according
to the report by the undergraduates
of Dartmouth, Johns Hopkins and
others."
This certainly is news to us. We
are not aware in the first place of
the existence of any socialistically
inclined students here at Hopkins,
and in the second place we do not
think that if there are any here,
they intend to form such a society
as the one described. If any such
plan is being considered, we wish
that it may be communicated to
THE NEWS-LETTER, so that we can
make an exclusive announcement
and can score a beat on our New
York contemporary.
With the organization this year
of the arbitration society we thought
that there were here at this Uniersity enough interests outside the
class-room, and when the musical
clubs were rejuvenated, this belief
was strenghtened. Apparently, if
the report of the Intercollegiate
Society is correct, we haven't
reached the end yet; and soon we
may have a Republican Club, a
Democratic Union, and a ProhibiStave off the
tion Sorority.
Socialistic society, please, as it
might serve as the forerunner for

criticism of a course that is required
of all undergraduates, we wish to
remind our readers that THE NEWSLETTER takes no responsibility for
views that are thus made public
further than to make sure that they
are bona fide utterances of readers
of the paper.
In the present case we agree with
the general idea of less lecture and
more recitation in undergraduate
courses,though we are not at all sure
that all that is said of the particular
course mentioned is justified. The
gi ound covered by the minor physics
course is extensive and only a
superficial knowledge of the subject
as a whole can be expected. If
the grades in the course average as
high as those in other compulsory
courses—and we believe they do—
it is evident that a satisfactory mastery of the work is obtained by most
of the students. To increase the
number of hours per week would
permit of more intensive study of
the science; but this, we believe,
is not the purpose of the course,
nor should it be so long as every
undergraduate is required to pursue
it. A general acquaintance with
the elements of physics the University holds to be necessary for a
liberal education; thorough mastery
of the science is only to be obtained
by those who devote their best efforts to it for a long period.

THE NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 21, 1910

TELESCOPES AND CRABS
Astronomy and Biology Divide Time of
Scientific Association—Ames and
Andrews Report Summer Trips.

• The first of the monthly meetings of the Scientific Association
was held last Wednesday at four
o'clock, in Hopkins Hall. Two
very interesting papers were given:
one by Professor Ames on the
meeting of the International Society for Solar Research, at Mt.
'Wilson, and the other by Professor
n:Irews on the expedition sent by
the University to Jamaica last summer.
The International Society for
Solar Research was formed in St.
Louis nine years ago when a num'ber of famous scientists happened
to he present in that city. Six
Years ago a meeting was held at
Oxford, England; three years later
one was held in Paris ; and in 1913
the Society will meet in Bonn, Germany. The meeting was held at
Mt. Wilson this summer, lai-gely
as a compliment to Professor Hale,
who is today unsurpassed in astronomical research. Scientists from
all over the world were present,
about forty from Europe, and forty
from America. The work of the
Society is divided 'among a number of permanent commttees which
make reports at the tri-yearly meetings.- These committees are:
The Committee on Standard
Wave Lengths, of which Professor
Ames is a member.
The Committee on Solar Eclipses.
It is evident that in order that
there may be successful observations, there should be some agreenient between the observatories as
to what they are to look for during the eclipses. That is one of
the functions of this committee.
Its other duties are to propose
Problems for investigation and to
devise instruments for the observation of eclipses of the sun. One
important question now being investigated is that of the constancy
of solar radiation. It was first
Observed by Professor. Langley
that for about six weeks there was
a diminution in the solar radiation, after which period it returned
to the normal amount. It is expected that when we learn more•
about solar radiation, we shall be
able to predict changes in the
Weather more certainly.
The Committee on Sun Spots.
Sun spots have been under 'observation from the time of Galileo.

Some years ago Professor Hale,
the director of the Mt. Wilson
observatory, discovered evidences
of a magnetic field around the sun
spots. He noticed also that the
spectrum of light issuing from or
near the sun spots was very different from the spectrum of ordinary sunlight. These discoveries
suggested many heretofore unsuspected phenomena.
The Committee on the Spectroheliograph. The Spectroheliograph
is an instrument by means of which
it is possible to observe the sun
by colored light. The surface of
the sun presents very different appearances when seen through glass
plates of different colors. In this
way we can learn a great deal
about the atmospheric conditions
on the sun. The principal work.
of this committee is to see that
spectroheliographs are constructed
and installed in all the observatories of the world, so that a continual watch can be kept on the
surface of the sun.
The second paper of the meeting was read by Professor Andrews. Professor Andrews gave a
short account of the previous relations of Johns Hopkins with the
island of Jamaica, from the time
when Professor Brooks established
the first laboratory at Kingston in
1891, to the fateful expedition to
Port Antonio, on which Professor
Humphreys and Dr. Conant lost
their lives. Then Professor Andrews described the surroundings
of the laboratory, the river, the islands with their mangrove swamps,
the coral reefs, all of which furnished abundant material for study.
The meeting was livened up a
bit by the live cabs which Dr.
Andrews brought in, two hermit
crabs, a white crab, and a black
crab. The latter animal is much
esteemed by the Jamaicans for
food, and bears a reputation comparable to that of our soft crabs.
The hermit crabs live on the land;
but once a year they go down to
the sea, traveling in an absolutely
straight line, crawling over all obstacles instead of going around
them, in order to deposit in the
water the young ones -which they
carry with them. The young stay
in the water for some time. Then
they crawl out and pick up a snailshell in which to live, and travel
up to the mountains, where they
are usually found.
Professor Andrews showed a
myriad of shells which .were collected in ponds. They were of

two kinds, the one small and
light-colored, the other large and
dark-colored. The small ones and
large ones were found in the same
pond within a short distance of
one another, and apparently under
the same conditions. But it was
found that the water in which the
dark-colored ones grew was slightly more saline, which apparently
influenced the size and color of
the shells.
Dr. Andrews was forced to cut
his talk somewhat short, because
of the lecture in McCoy Hall. But
he said sufficient to show the great
value of these expeditions to the
tropics.
Medical Society Hears Papers.

The Johns Hopkins Hospital
Medical Society met on Monday
evening, November 14, in the Medical Ampitheatre. There was an
attendance of about one hundred
and fifty. The first paper was by
Drs. Wm. S. Thayer and Roger S.
Morris (read by the former) on
"Two Cases of Congenital Hemolytic Jaundice." The paper was illustrated by microscopic preparations. After its conclusion the subject was further discussed by Dr.
W. L. Moss.
, Dr. J. Staige Davis read a most
interesting article upon "Wounds
of the Scalp and Their Treatment
by Skin-Grafting." After reviewing the history of this subject he
reported cases which came under
his own direct observation, and
concluded with a series of lantern
slides illustrating the operations
discussed.
Lectures on History of Religions.

Professor J. J. M. de Groot, of
the University of Leyden, will give
six lectures in McCoy Hall at 5
p. in. His subject will be "The
Development of Religious Ideas
in China." .The topics and dates
are as follows:
November 23—The Tao or Order
of the Universe.
November 28—The Tao of Man.
November 30—Holiness.
December 2—Asceticism. The
Prolongation of Life.
December 5—Worship of the
Universe.
December 6—Social and Political Taoism.
Cards of admission will not be
requisite. The door will be closed
when the lecturer rises.

HARLEY TUTTLE CAVERLY, '13
Haney Tuttle Caverly,a student in
the second-year class of the Medical
School, died on Monday, Nov. 14,
in the Johns Hopkins Hospital. He
was attacked about two weeks before
with severe abdominal trouble, for
which two operations were performed in vain. Mr. Caverly was a
resident of Rutland, Vermont. He
was an A. B. of Dartmouth College
in the class of 1909.
At a meeting of his class on Wednesday, November 16, the following
resolutions were adopted:
"We, the members of the class of
1913 of Johns .Hopkins Medical
School, wish to express to the family of our esteemed and beloved
classmate, Harley Tuttle Caverly,
our deep appreciation of his life
among us, and to extend to them
our heartfelt sympathy in their
bereavement.
At a meeting of the class it was
decided that a copy of this expression of our affection and sympathy
be published in THE NEWS-LETTER."
The class also sent flowers to
the funeral, which will take place
in Rutland, Vt.
Lecture on French Comedy.

Professor Giroud, of Girard College, Philadelphia, delivered the
second ot his series of talks on
the French comedy of the Eighteenth Century, arranged by the Alliance Francaise, in McCoy Hall at
noon Saturday. The topic was
Lesage's —rurcaret." Professor
Giroud is well known in educational
circles and among the members of
the Baltimore group of the Alliance,
and his lectures are attracting considerable attention. There are nine
more in the course. Next Saturday M. Louis Delamarre, of the
City College of New York, will be
the lecturer, speaking on "French
Humorists."

(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged
to make use of this column.)
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

Has it every occurred to any of
the innocent freshmen who are so
assiduously warned at the weekly
"Hygiene Lectures" to beware of
dirt, that the towels hanging in the
gymnasium are changed rather infrequently and may, therefore, be
the breeding place for the same
, germs for whose eradication the application of hygienic principles
labors? Does it not seem ironical
to the upper-classmen that the
building that contains exhibits of
advanced metods of pasteurization
and utensils for the thorough cleaning of drinking cups, should have
scattered through it cups used by
almost all members of the University, that are put in position once
and are replaced only when they
leak? Certainly an institution so
intimately connected as is ours with
the leading school of preventive
medicine in the country should be
more careful of its students.

The second lecture was
occupied with a discussion of the
peoples of Europe, that meetingplace of races. Most of the races
belong, however, to the same great
type of humanity, the one which has
at various times been called the
white, the Mediterranean, and the
Caucasian to distinguish it from
the black, the red, the yellow, and
the brown types.
In Dr. Oberhummer's opinion,
the earliest appearance of man in
Europe was in the Paleolithic Age.
To be sure, various unfashioned instruments have been unearthed,
. which are by some supposed to
betray the existence of Neolithic
men; but the earliest human bones
discovered belong to the Paleolithic
Age. Several skulls dating from
this period have been found in Germany, and some complete skeletons
in France; but it is as yet uncertain
whether or not these are the relics
of the ancestors of man, or of some
collateral descendants of a common
ancestor.
There are traces,Dr.Oberhummer
said, that the whole west of Europe
was once inhabited by men of
negro type. The east was at the
same time occupied by a people
resembling the Mongols. The chief
distinguishing mark between these
two races is the shape of the skull,
which in the case of the former is
elongated, in that of the latter
broadened. At present there are
three .types of man in Europe: in
the north a type tall of stature,
long of skull, blond of complexion;
in the center a type stocky of stature,
long of skull, and dark of complexion (not Celtic but Siberian) ;
and in the Alps a peculiar type with
a small round skull and a middle
stature.
The blond type is peculiar to
Europe; and, furthermore, it was to
be found originally only in the
Scandinavian peninsula and on the
shores of the Baltic. A peculiar
fact is that at the time of the appearance of man in southern and
western Europe, all this territory
was covered with a great ice-sheet.
Evidently, the blond type is a composite of post-glacial origin.
Dr. Oberhummer warned his
audience not to place too much confidence in philology as an aid to
the study of ethnology. Language,
he said, was the product rather of
historical than ethnological events;
and cited the cases of the Roumanians and of the Basques to prove his
contention.
